job_title: User Support Specialist in Springfield, MO
pros: Everyone in the department are really nice people and get along great. Tuition remission is a good benefit.
cons: Pay is lower the the local market average, and questionable leadership decisions can be demoralizing.

pros: Drury is a small, friendly, and tight-knit campus. In all my interactions, the faculty and staff were committed to helping their students learn and succeed and would go to great lengths to do so. The students I interacted with were serious about and committed to their education.
cons: The campus has experienced some financial mismanagement from a previous administration that the current administration is continuing to recover from. Pay is pretty terrible, even for higher ed. The campus infrastructure is lacking--our department lacked any software systems standard for our field. There are several departments in which simple automation could significantly improve services, but staff cannot afford to (or don't know how to) implement it.

pros: Pros: - Beautiful campus: Drury University's campus is truly stunning. The well-manicured lawns, historic buildings, and lovely landscaping make working here a visual treat. - Tuition remission: The university offers a tuition remission program for its employees, which is a great perk for those interested in furthering their education. - Sense of community: Drury University has a small, tight-knit community that fosters a strong sense of camaraderie among employees from many different departments.
cons: Cons: - Low salary: One major downside of working at Drury University is the extremely low salary. This can make it difficult to make ends meet, especially in a city with an increasing cost of living. - Limited opportunities for advancement: Due to the small size of the university, there may be limited opportunities for career advancement for some employees. - Heavy workload: Some employees may find themselves with a heavy workload due to understaffing, which can lead to stress and burnout.

pros: Very kind, motivating people who genuinely care about you. The amount of time off is decent, but comparable to most other companies. Campus is beautiful.
cons: The pay is very low and you will hardly be able to pay your bills if you have an entry level position at Drury. $35,000-40,000 is the average among most positions. They try and compensate the extremely low pay with boasting benefits, but the benefits are no better than most other companies.

pros: culture, benefits, co-workers, facilities, leadership
cons: low pay, little room for growth

pros: Positive work environment Benefits Time-off Tuition Remissions Connections
cons: Pay N/A N/A N/A N/A

review_title: Nice staff and faculty, small liberal arts is struggling to stay afloat
pros: Staff and faculty are incredibly knowledgeable, kind and good to work with. Generous vacation and paid time off. Tuition remission and tuition exchange are wonderful benefits.
cons: Low pay Difficult to recruit students to the university. Campus is somewhat outdated and aside from tuition cost, there is no real educational benefit that differentiates them from other larger universities.

pros: A lot of time off
cons: poor pay, lack of leadership, no clear definition of goals and unqualified coworkers

pros: Pretty chill place, just mow
cons: Students can be turds at time

pros: Some of the best staff but depends on which department you work in.
cons: Drury University is toxic. Students and staff are seen as nothing more than commodities by leadership. You will spend more time getting passive-aggressive comments or micro-managed then you will trust and honest feedback. Pay is low for the area, and the "benefits" are that it feels like "family" (Only if your family is expendable.) Constantly taking budget cuts and being asked to do more and more with less and less. This place is about to burst from being mismanaged. too much internal hiring with toxic politics. No advancement opportunities.

pros:
Flexible work environment, but it completely depends on your specific supervisor.
Nice PTO benefits
Closed during Christmas (usually)
Beautiful campus
cons:
The school boosts about how it gives students such a personal tailored experience, but administration treats employees like numbers and as like garbage.
There is no consistency. One office operates under completely different rules and guidelines than another and then administration enforces policy at their own whims. 
Are not supportive of women in the workforce and women suffer if they request FMLA leave. 
High turnover of upper administration positions and they often come in and clean house or layoff longtime employees, then move on to another job.

review_title: Go for the people - not the salary
pros: Great people to work with on a daily basis.
cons: Management isn't willing to listen to new ideas and compensation is lacking for the amount of work for the position

review_title: Department chairs and professors are wonderful to work for
pros: Great group of people to work for and with
cons: Does not pay well. They need to re-evaluate this.

job_title: Tenured Full Professor in Springfield, MO
pros: Good colleagues, smarter than average students, and Springfield is a decent mid size US city
cons: Erosion of any real faculty governance, pay very much under market value, leadership bloat. Springfield is VERY conservative and VERY religious as a community (I know that's a pro for some, but is very much a con for me.)

pros: Great sense of community. Students are first and foremost thought of when decisions are made. Historical environment that feel comfortable. Beautiful campus.
cons: Pay is lower than similar jobs in area. Leadership is a bit top heavy and can sometimes be a detriment.

review_title: The students are the best part of the job!
pros: There are a lot of wonderful people working at Drury
cons: Leadership will blame others, instead of owning up to their mistakes.

pros:
150 years of history and tradition
Amazing benefits including free education and casual summers
Room for advancement around campus
cons: Industry is reinventing itself means occasional change

job_title: Director of Media Relations in Springfield, MO
pros: Renowned institution...great people in most departments...long-term stability...alumni care greatly about the university.
cons: University's leadership is self-centered...institution is currently being run as if it is cash-starved...seems to be a lack-of-knowledge on how to grow an enrollment base without adding new sports and activities (adding those only adds to the cost of operating the campus).

review_title: An OK employer, use your benefits!
pros: Had good benefits if you used them.
cons: Low starting salary. Seniority, shift assignments, and promotion criteria were rarely honored. Poor career opportunities.

pros: I work for my theatre department so I only have to report to my theatre professors
cons: Drury does not care about the arts

pros: very friendly people at university
cons: not paid what one is worth

job_title: Academic Advisor in Saint Robert, MO
pros: Will hire with little to no experience in higher education

pros: University community puts students first
cons: The location could be better

pros: Great people, great atmosphere, great everything!
cons: No cons, working at Drury is the best job I've ever had.

pros: Good environment. Good people. Overall Good everything.
cons: Lack of communication at times.

pros:
* Low stress environment
* Steady pay
* There is always something to do
cons: * The maintenance Dept really needs a bigger budget. There is a plethora of antiquated equipment scattered throughout campus.  The vehicles are very poor and probably use up alot of the budget. School owned tools are worn out and we usually have to use used parts from our salvage items in storage which resulted in frequent call backs on work orders. Pay is only once a month so sharpen your budgeting skills. Pay is lower than average but there are those Pros up above.

review_title: Great people, family atmosphere, in financial trouble
pros: Employees are very friendly, warm and welcoming.  They truly treat each other like a family and are always willing to help out on any project. Most departments have very flexible work hours.  Employees get lots of time off other than holidays and vacation days such as a week off between Christmas and New Year's and half days on Fridays in the summer.
cons: The university is in some serious financial trouble right now.  Every year we are told we have to slash our budgets another 5, 10 or even 20%.  No one has had a raise in 5 or 6 years and our employee contribution for health insurance has gone up and our health benefits have gone down.  Employees are leaving every week for better paying, more secure jobs elsewhere and their positions are not being filled which requires the rest of us to pick up the extra work.  Some people are doing the work that used to take 2 or 3 people to do.

pros: Office culture is nice, people there are trying to help you, very friendly. Enough time to complete your tasks (unless in admissions), some perks like 10% employee discount in an overpriced bookstore. Work/life balance is good, nobody is pressuring you if you are having problems outside of work.
cons: High turnover in admissions, lack of promotion possibilities

review_title: I learned more from this job than most of the professors.
pros: You can work and go to school at the same time. The people are kind, and the area is nice. Lots of support from management.
cons: Pay can be an issue if you are a student worker.  Your hours are generally limited to around 15-20 a week.

pros: Colleagues are wonderful and so are the students..
cons: No raises for many years.  Services have declined with cut backs and letting go of staff.

pros: great benefits including 100% tuition remission for employee spouse and children after one year. great staff work environment.
cons: constant leadership changes resulting in a general lack of institutional continuity at all levels; no raises for quite some time now.

review_title: Great company with a few hiccups...

Solid benefits (health, tuition remission, retirement match)
Culture committed to wellness
cons:
Overall communication within the institution.
Pay.

pros: I worked in the Office of Community Outreach & Leadership Development. I loved the flexibility they gave me with my work projects and responsibilities.
cons: The only cons I can think of are situational- nothing within the institution itself.
